questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of mild pain in his right shoulder following a minor fall. The X-ray is shown below. There is no significant swelling or erythema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Simple Bone Cyst

 

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a fragment of bone within the cyst cavity following a fracture (Falling leaf sign), suggestive of a simple bone cyst.

 

Simple Bone Cyst (SBC) / Unicameral bone cyst

A solitary, usually unilocular, cystic bone cavity filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid and lined by a fibrous membrane.

Epidemiology

Age: Presents in the first two decades of life.

Sex: More common in males. (2:1)

Location

Commonly affects the metaphysis close to the physis.

Most frequently occurs in the proximal humerus, proximal femur, and proximal tibia.

Presentation

Often asymptomatic, discovered incidentally.

Pathological fracture is a common presentation.

Types

Active cyst: If the cyst is situated close to the epiphyseal plate.

Latent cyst: If the cyst moves away from the growth plate.

Radiological Features

X-ray:

Well-outlined, lytic lesion located centrally in the metaphysis.

Expands and thins the cortex.

Fallen leaf sign: a small bone fragment within the cyst cavity following a fracture

Trap-door sign: a small bone fragment hinges at the cortex.

 

MRI: Homogeneous, fluid-filled cavity.

Histology

Connective tissue lining with foci of reactive bone.

It has characteristic giant cells.

Treatment

Percutaneous steroid injections for active lesions.

Curettage and bone grafting.

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A): It presents with aggressive bone destruction, periosteal reaction (sunburst appearance), and not typically with a central, lytic lesion.

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (Option B): It is more expansile and often multiloculated. It typically causes more severe pain and swelling.

Fibrous Dysplasia (Option C): It typically shows a "ground-glass" appearance on X-ray, not a simple lytic lesion with a "fallen leaf sign."

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of the indicated arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given X-ray shows an elevated periosteum
  • All of the options mentioned above can show periosteal elevation

 

Differentials of elevated periosteum

Vascular
  • Haemophilia and other bleeding disorders
  • Myeloid metaplasia (thrombocytopenia)
  • Erythroblastic anemias
  • Leukaemias
  • Varicose veins
  • Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy
  • Pachydermoperiostosis

Physiologic
  • Prematurity

Dysplastic
  • Melorheostosis
  • Engelmann's disease

Traumatic
  • Local subperiosteal trauma
  • Fractures (including march fractures)
  • Unrecognized skeletal trauma (Caffey's syndrome)

Hypo/Hypervitaminosis
  • Rickets
  • Scurvy
  • Hypervitaminosis A

Infective
  • Acute osteomyelitis (staphylococcal, streptococcal, pneumococcal)
  • Brodie's abscess
  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis (congenital and acquired)

Neoplastic
  • Primary:
    • Benign :meningioma, angioma, osteoid osteoma
    • Malignant: osteogenic sarcoma (only this is called Codman's triangle), fibrosarcoma, Ewing's sarcoma
  • Secondary: metastatic bony deposits

Endocrine
  • Thyroid acropachy
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism in renal osteodystrophy

Primary Joint Lesions
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile chronic arthritis (Still's disease)
  • Reiter's syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Osteoarthritis (femoral neck only)

Congenital
  • Tuberous sclerosis

Miscellaneous
  • Infantile cortical hyperostosis
  • Histiocytosis

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the visit, he shared his family history of bone tumors, mentioning that several relatives have passed away from various types of bone cancers. Concerned about his own risk, he asks the doctor which type of bone malignancy he should be most vigilant about.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Multiple Myeloma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Multiple myeloma is the most common bone tumor in older adults, particularly those aged above 40 years.
  • It originates from malignant plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • Given the patient’s age, multiple myeloma is a significant concern.

 

Osteochondroma (Option A): The most common age group is teenagers.

 

Osteoclastoma (Option B): Occurs between 15-35 years of age.

 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option C): Occurs between 15-25 years of age.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with persistent pain and swelling in her right knee that has been worsening over the past few months. During her family history discussion, her mother recalls that a distant relative had primary bone cancer in their youth. Concerned about the possibility of a serious condition, the girl asks the doctor which type of bone malignancy is most commonly seen in adolescents like her.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteogenic Sarcoma

 

Explanation:

  • Osteogenic sarcoma (osteosarcoma) is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in adolescents, typically occurring around the knee.
  • Given the girl's age, osteosarcoma is the most relevant malignancy to consider.

 

Osteosarcoma

Type

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma)

Origin

Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin

Tissue Origin

Solid malignant bone tumor

Age Group

Bimodal distribution: peaks in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade

Gender Prevalence

More common in males than females

Common Sites

1. Lower end of femur

2. Upper end of tibia

Location of Origin

Arises from the metaphysis of long bones



 

Synovial sarcoma (Option B): Uncommon malignant tumor.

 

Reticulum cell sarcoma (Option C): Uncommon malignant tumor.

 

Ewing’s sarcoma (Option D): Ewing sarcoma is not the most common malignant bone tumor, but it is the second most common in children and young adults.

All of the following are correctly matched bone tumors except?

Correct Answer: B) 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most common benign bone tumor is: Osteochondroma

1. Most common bone tumors

Pb KTL (Lead Kettle)

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with a two-week history of left thumb pain and swelling. She has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and triple-negative carcinoma of mammary origin, diagnosed five years prior. Physical examination reveals swelling and mild ulceration at the distal first phalanx. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most common underlying cause of the patient's thumb lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary carcinoma from another site

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most common underlying cause of the thumb lesion in this case is secondary carcinoma from Breast carcinoma because:
    • The patient has a history of triple-negative carcinoma of mammary origin (Breast Ca) indicating metastasis to the distal phalanx.
    • The X-ray findings indicate a lytic lesion.

Metastatic Tumors to Bone

Common Metastatic Tumors
  • Lung carcinoma (male)
  • Breast carcinoma (female)
  • Prostate carcinoma (Osteoblastic)
  • Thyroid carcinoma

Clinical Features
  • Known Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain (common in spine, ribs, extremities)
    • Pathological fracture (common in spine)
 
  • Unknown Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain leading to destructive lesion diagnosis
    • Pathological fracture due to weakened bone

Malignancies Presenting with Silent Primary
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma

Common Sites of Metastasis
  • Vertebral bodies
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis
  • Humerus
  • Femur
  • Uncommon distal to elbow and knee

 

Primary osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Typical presentation in younger individuals, along with different radiographic features(Sunburst appearance).
  • Not associated with previous history of Breast cancer.

 

Secondary osteosarcoma (Option C):

  • Usually associated with a known primary bone condition(Paget’s disease)

 

Osteoclastoma (Option D):

  • Found in younger adults
  • Primarily affects the epiphysis of long bones

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of progressively worsening thigh pain, initially accompanied by intermittent fevers and malaise. Recently, her pain has intensified to the point of bedridden status. She develops acute confusion and altered consciousness, with laboratory tests revealing severe hypercalcemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ewing's sarcoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ewing's sarcoma is the most likely diagnosis due to:
    • The patient's age (20 year old)
    • The presence of progressively worsening thigh pain (femur), and severe hypercalcemia, which is atypical but has been documented in cases of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The X-ray findings of lytic bone lesions align with the aggressive nature of this tumor and can lead to significant complications, including pathological fractures and systemic symptoms.

Feature

Ewing's Sarcoma

Multiple Myeloma (Plasmacytoma)

Age Group Affected

4–25 years

40–60 years

Sex Distribution

More common in males

Equally affects males and females

Primary Site

Long bones (femur, tibia, fibula, humerus)

Bone (typically spine, skull, pelvis, ribs)

Location

Diaphysis of long bones

Various bones, often vertebrae

Symptoms

Intermittent pain, worse at night, fever

Severe back pain, weakness, weight loss

Physical Examination

Fixed tumor, red skin, dilated veins

Local tenderness, possible pathological fractures

Radiographic Features

Lytic, sclerotic, or mixed lesions; periosteal onion peel appearance; moth-eaten destruction

Diffuse osteoporosis, lytic lesions; biconcave vertebrae; punched-out lesions in skull and pelvis

Histological Features

Sheets of small, uniform cells resembling lymphocytes; pseudo-rosettes may be present

Round cells with eccentrically placed nuclei; sparse chromatin arranged in a “spokes of wheel” pattern; perinuclear halo typically not seen

Prognosis

Poor 5-year survival rate

Variable, but generally better than Ewing's

Common Complications

Metastasis to lungs and other organs

Pathological fractures, neurological symptoms


 

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma typically presents with pain localized to the knee region (distal femur or proximal tibia).
  • Shows characteristic radiographic features such as a sunburst pattern.

 

Multiple myeloma (Option C):

  • Affects older adults, usually between ages 40 and 70.
  • "Punched-out" lytic lesions on X-ray and diffuse osteopenia, particularly affecting the vertebrae and skull.
  • While it can present with bone pain and hypercalcemia, it usually comes with systemic symptoms such as "CRAB" symptoms (hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, bone lesions).

 

Osteoclastoma (Option D):

  • Most commonly occurs around the knee, particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia.
  • usually presents with local pain and swelling but is less commonly associated with systemic symptoms like intermittent fevers and malaise.
  • Shows soap bubble appearance on Xray

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of worsening back pain, fatigue, and significant weight loss. He also reports frequent headaches, difficulty concentrating, and numbness in his legs. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lumbar spine and decreased sensation in the lower extremities. Laboratory investigations show normocytic anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum creatinine. Urinalysis reveals the presence of Bence Jones proteins. A skeletal survey is done. Which of the following is NOT a typical radiological feature of the patient’s most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sunburst appearance in long bones

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and investigation findings are highly suggestive of multiple myeloma.
  • All of the options except sunburst appearance are typical radiological features in a case of multiple myeloma.
  • Sunburst appearance in long bones is characteristic of osteosarcoma.

 

Multiple myeloma:

  • It is the most common primary malignant bone tumor.
  • It is the malignant proliferation of plasma cells of the B-cell lineage within the bone marrow.
  • Common age group: Around 70 years of age.
  • Men > Female.

 

Pathology:

  • Increased production of plasma paraprotein and immunoglobulin.
  • Tumor tissue replaces the bone and there is no reactive bone formation.

 

Histopathology:

  • Bone marrow is hypercellular and diffusely infiltrated by plasma cells.

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Severe pain in the lumbar and thoracic spine is the most common symptom.
  • Pathological fractures.
  • Local tenderness over the affected bones.
  • Fatigue, and loss of weight.
  • Neurological symptoms.
  • Medical complications: Anaemia, hypercalcemia, hyperviscosity, immunosuppression, and renal dysfunction.

 

Investigations:

  • Skeletal survey to screen for bone lesions, and assess tumor burden and fracture risk: X-rays of the spine, skull, pelvis, ribs/sternum, and the humerus/femurs.
  • Multiple punched-out lesions in the skull and other flat bones. In the skull, it may cause a ‘pepper-pot’ appearance. (Options A & B ruled out)


  • Pathological wedge collapse of the vertebra (Common in the thoracic spine). (Option C ruled out)

A. A lateral X-ray of the lumbar spine shows diffuse osteopenia and a pathologic compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body (arrow).

B. A midsagittal T2-weighted MRI taken several months later shows extensive marrow infiltration and compression fractures of many vertebral bodies.


 

  • CT is superior to X-ray for demonstrating fractures, osteolytic lesions, and soft-tissue masses.
  • Urine: Bence Jones proteins
  • Serum electrophoresis: Abnormal spike in the gamma globulin region (myeloma spike).
  • Bone marrow biopsy:
    • From the iliac crest.
    • CT guided needle biopsy from the vertebral lesion.

 

Treatment:

  • Treatment of choice: Autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT).
  • Bisphosphonates to control hypercalcemia.
  • In transplant-ineligible patients:
    • Bortezomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (VRd).
    • Daratumumab, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (DRd).

questions.text: A 25-year-old male has pain and progressive swelling around the proximal part of the left hand for the last 3 months. The X-ray is shown below. A biopsy reveals small, round cells forming pseudo-rosettes. Which of the following is not correct regarding the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: It is a highly malignant tumor of bone, commonly involving diaphysis.
The tumor is highly radio-sensitive but prone to recurrence.
Males are more likely to be affected than females.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bone-to-bone metastasis is not common.

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture and onion peel appearance in the proximal part of the shaft of the left humerus on the X-ray are consistent with a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • Bone-to-bone metastasis is very common, making metastasis a frequent and challenging complication.

 

Ewing's sarcoma

  • Highly malignant tumor. (Option A ruled out)
  • Cell of origin: Mesenchymal stem cells in the bone marrow.
  • Age group: 10-20 years of age.
  • Males > Females. (Option D ruled out)
  • Common site: Diaphysis of the long bone. Femur > tibia > humerus > fibula.

 

Histopathology:

The tumor cells surround a central clear area, forming a pseudo-rosette.

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • The earliest symptom is pain.
  • Later symptoms are swelling and low-grade fever.
  • Swelling is usually located in the diaphysis and has features of a malignant swelling.
  • Very poor prognosis.
  • Bone-to-bone metastasis is very common. (Option B)

 

X-ray findings:

  • Onion-peel appearance- new bone formation in layers.

  • Lytic lesion in the medullary zone of the midshaft of a long bone with cortical destruction.
  • In flat bones, it is primarily a lytic lesion with no new bone formation.

 

Treatment

Combined therapy:

  • Radiotherapy: Highly radio-sensitive tumor so melts quickly but has recurrence (Option C ruled out)
  • Wide surgical excision
  • Chemotherapy.

 

Reference:

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female is diagnosed with a giant cell tumor in her distal femur after presenting with vague pain and swelling. She undergoes surgical excision of the tumor.
Which of the following pre-operative X-ray findings is most consistent with giant cell tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Soap bubble appearance

 

Explanation: Soap bubble appearance is the characteristic radiological finding of giant cell tumors. It presents as a lytic lesion with multiple internal septations, giving it a soap bubble appearance. It is usually located in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the distal femur.

 

X-ray findings in Giant cell tumors (GCTs):

  • Eccentric location, often subchondral.
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
  • The cortex may be thinned out.
  • Lobulated lytic lesions with narrow zones of transition produce a soap bubble appearance. (Option C)

  • No calcification within the tumor.
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.
  • The tumor usually does not enter the adjacent joint.

 

Treatment:

  • The treatment of choice is excision.
  • Followed by reconstruction procedures and bone grafting or polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) insertion.
  • Adjuvant treatments:
    • Liquid nitrogen and phenol have been shown to decrease recurrences.
    • Bisphosphonates like zoledronate or pamidronate
  • Radiotherapy- especially for spine GCTs
  • Drugs:
    • Denosumab- anti-RANKL monoclonal antibody.


 

Sun-rays appearance (Option A):

  • It is typically seen in osteosarcoma.
  • As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor which resembles rays of the sun.

Onion peel appearance (Option B):

  • It is associated with Ewing's sarcoma.
  • It refers to concentric layers of rapid new periosteal bone formation that resemble the layers of an onion.

Pepper pot appearance (Option D):

  • It is commonly seen in multiple myeloma.
  • The pepper pot or punched-out appearance refers to multiple small, round lytic lesions in the skull caused by the tumor.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive and persistent vague pain and swelling around her right knee for the past 3 months. On physical examination, there is swelling around the distal femur with tenderness. Histopathology shows multinucleated giant cells and spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells. Which of the following statements is true regarding the nature of the tumor in this patient?

choices.text: It commonly arises from the diaphysis of long bones
It is benign but can behave aggressively locally
It most frequently metastasizes to regional lymph nodes
It most commonly affects individuals under the age of 20

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is benign but can behave aggressively locally

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestation and histopathological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of a giant cell tumor.
  • It is classified as benign but can behave aggressively in the local area, causing extensive bone destruction.

 

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor

  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone. (Option B)
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis. (Option A ruled out)
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age. (Option D ruled out)
  • Females > males.
  • Most Common sites affected: Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases. (Option C ruled out)

 

Histopathology:

  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Clinical features:

  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents to orthopedics OPD with mild fever and intermittent thigh pain for the past several months, particularly at night. There is no history of fever and weight loss. On physical exam, there is swelling and tenderness over the distal femur. An X-ray image is shown below.



Which of the following best explains the radiological finding in osteosarcoma that is marked with an arrow in the above image?

choices.text: It represents tumor calcification within the bone
It is a result of the tumor breaking through the periosteum, lifting it off the bone
It indicates early metastasis to the nearby soft tissue

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is a result of the tumor breaking through the periosteum, lifting it off the bone

 

Explanation: The triangular shadow seen on the X-ray is Codman’s triangle. It results from rapid tumor growth in osteosarcoma, which lifts the periosteum off the bone.

 

X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:

  • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.
  • Sun-ray appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor. (Option A ruled out)

 

  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle. (Option C)

CT scan is primarily used to assist with biopsy and disease staging.

 

Treatment

Combination of therapy:

  • Surgical amputation is the treatment of choice- complete removal of the tumor must be ensured. Limb-salvage procedures have become possible and popular.
  • Radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy
    • Doxorubicin
    • Cisplatin
    • Ifosfamide
    • Methotrexate
  • Follow-up: Every 6-8 weeks. Evidence of recurrence of the primary tumor or appearance of the secondary (usually in the chest) is diagnosed early and treated.

 

It represents tumor calcification within the bone (Option B): Calcifications in osteosarcoma typically occur in the osteoid matrix produced by the tumor, but Codman’s triangle is related to periosteal elevation, not tumor calcification.

 

It indicates early metastasis to the nearby soft tissue (Option D): Osteosarcoma can spread to soft tissues, but Codman’s triangle is related to periosteal elevation rather than distant spread or metastasis.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling and pain around her left ankle for the past 6 months. The pain is worse at night and unresponsive to analgesics. On examination, there is a firm, poorly defined, tender mass over the distal femur, with shiny skin and prominent veins over the swelling. The X-ray is shown below.



Which of the following is true regarding the most common site of origin for the bone tumor that the patient is having in this case?

choices.text: Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metaphysis of long bones

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the demographics of the patient, clinical manifestation, and X-ray showing sunburst appearance, the most probable diagnosis is osteosarcoma.
  • It most commonly originates in the metaphysis of long bones.

 

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

  • Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin/ solid malignant bone tumor.
  • Age group: Bimodal age distribution peaking in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.
  • Gender: Males >> Female

 

Pathology:

  • Origin: It arises from mesenchymal cells.
  • Common site: From the metaphysis or meta-diaphysis. (Option C)
  • Order of frequency: Lower-end of the femur > upper-end of the tibia > upper-end of the humerus.

 

 

  • All osteosarcomas are aggressive and metastasize widely through the hematogenous route, typically to the lungs.
  • Despite its aggressiveness, it seldom penetrates the epiphyseal plate. (Option D ruled out)

 

Histopathology:

  • Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumor cells surrounded by osteoid.

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Worsening pain and swelling, particularly night pain.
  • Pathological fracture is rare.
  • On examination:
    • Shiny skin with prominent veins over swelling.
    • Poorly defined, warm, and tender swelling.
    • Adjacent joint movement may be limited due to swelling.
    • The tumor may compress neurovascular structures, causing symptoms.
    • Usually reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes.
  • Associated syndromes with osteosarcoma development:
    • Li–Fraumeni (p53 tumor suppressor gene mutation)
    • Hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes
    • Rothmund–Thomson syndrome


 

Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma arises from mesenchymal cells, not hematopoietic cells.
  • Hematopoietic cells are more commonly associated with multiple myeloma.

Diaphysis of long bones (Option B):

  • Ewing sarcoma commonly originates in the diaphysis of long bones, and osteosarcoma most commonly arises from the metaphysis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with pain and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray shows an expansile lytic lesion in the epiphysis extending to the metaphysis. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) reveals a bloody aspirate with hemosiderin-laden macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aneurysmal bone cyst

 

Explanation:

An aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is often characterized by an expansile, lytic lesion, and its FNA typically yields a bloody aspirate due to the cystic, vascular nature of the lesion. Hemosiderin-laden macrophages are commonly seen due to prior hemorrhage within the cyst.

 

Giant cell tumor (GCT) (Option A) can also present as an expansile lytic lesion, but it usually involves the epiphysis without such a significant cystic, vascular component or bloody aspirate on FNA.

 

 

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)

Age

Primarily affects children and teenagers

Most common in young adults (15-35 years)

Gender

Equal distribution between males and females

More common in females (Female: Male ratio 1.5:1)

Location

Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus), spine

Epiphyses of long bones (lower end of femur, upper end of tibia)

Symptoms

Pain and swelling; spinal lesions may cause neurological issues

Swelling without pain; late stages show joint limitation and pathological fracture

Histology

FNAC: Hemosiderin +

Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae

FNAC: No hemosiderin

Abundant giant cells with multiple nuclei (>150), spindle cells indicating malignancy

Radiology

Osteolytic lesion, multiple septations and fluid-fluid levels on MRI

Thin septa with soap-bubble appearance on X-ray, cortex thin and expanded, no periosteal reaction

Treatment

Curettage, debridement, and in some cases radiation (cautiously)

Surgical excision with PMMA or bone grafting; Denosumab and bisphosphonates as adjunct therapy

Osteosarcoma (Option C): It is a malignant tumor that presents with mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and periosteal reactions rather than a purely lytic, expansile lesion with a bloody aspirate.

Chondroblastoma (Option D): It is a rare benign tumor that affects the epiphysis, usually seen in younger patients, but it does not typically show a bloody aspirate or hemosiderin deposits on FNA.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with a gradually enlarging, painful swelling over the distal femur. On examination, the swelling is tender and firm. X-ray shows an expansile, lytic lesion with multiple fluid levels in the metaphysis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aneurysmal bone cyst

 

Explanation:

Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a benign, expansile, osteolytic lesion that commonly affecmetaphysis of long bones in adolescents.

 

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

A benign, expansile bone lesion composed of blood-filled cystic spaces.

Epidemiology

Primarily affects children and teenagers (10 to 30 years).

Males > Females

Location

Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus).

Located subperiosteally.

Presentation

Pain and Swelling.

Radiological Features

X-ray: Radiolucent area situated at the metaphysis.

Osteolytic, poorly defined lesion elevating and eroding the cortex.

MRI: Multiple intralesional septations and fluid levels.

Angiography: Persistence of contrast and a blush of flow within the lesion.

Histology

Composed of blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae.

In chronic cases, the septae may contain woven bone.

Treatment

Surgery: Curettage and bone grafting


 

Giant cell tumor (Option A): It usually occurs in adults near the ends of long bones, show a lytic lesion without fluid levels, and often extend into the subchondral bone.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): It is a malignant bone tumor that presents with aggressive, mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and periosteal reactions like Codman's triangle or sunburst appearance.

Osteoid osteoma (Option D): It is a small, benign lesion typically causing nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs, and appears as a small nidus surrounded by sclerosis on imaging.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of a slowly growing, painless swelling on the forehead for the past 3 years. On examination, a hard, immobile mass is palpated. A CT scan shows a dense, well-circumscribed, bony lesion in the frontal sinus. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ivory osteoma

 

Explanation:

The given scenario with a history of a slowly growing, painless swelling on the forehead and a CT scan showing a dense, well-circumscribed, bony lesion in the frontal sinus is suggestive of Ivory osteoma.

 

Ivory Osteoma / Compact Osteoma:

It is a painless condition affecting membranous bones or soft tissues.

Two Types

  • Homoplastic: arises purely from bone
  • Heteroplastic: arises from soft tissues

Most common site: The outer surface of the Skull (especially in front of the frontal sinus)

Presentations:

  • Cosmetic problems
  • Mucocele.
  • It can become a space-occupying lesion (if the inner table of the skull is involved) and can predispose to epilepsy.

Treatment: Excision

 

Fibrous dysplasia (Option A) is a benign bone disorder where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, often presenting as ground-glass opacity on imaging rather than a dense, sclerotic lesion. This option is incorrect.

Osteosarcoma (Option B) is a malignant bone tumor that typically presents with pain, aggressive growth, and mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance on imaging, unlike the slow-growing, dense ivory osteoma. This option is incorrect.

A dermoid cyst (Option D) is mobile when palpated and does not appear bony on a CT. This option is incorrect.

 

Reference:

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with persistent pain in his right leg, which is worse at night and relieved by ibuprofen. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no swelling or warmth over the affected area. An X-ray of the right leg is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Osteoid Osteoma

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presenting with persistent pain, relieved by NSAIDs and an X-ray showing a characteristic lesion with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus, points towards an Osteoid Osteoma.

 

Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics
  • Sex: Males > Females
  • Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location
  • The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.
  • It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms
  • Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).
  • When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.
  • In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

  • Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.
  • The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology
  • Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.
  • The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment
  • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

 

Simple bone cyst (Option A):

  • It is usually asymptomatic and occurs in the metaphysis.
  • On X-rays, it appears as a well-marginated, unilocular lytic lesion with a thin rim of sclerosis.

 

Brodie’s Abscess (Option C):

  • It is a subacute form of osteomyelitis that presents with localized pain, often associated with low-grade infection.
  • It can also have a radiolucent lesion but is usually accompanied by systemic signs like fever and swelling.

 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option D):

  • It usually presents with systemic symptoms like fever and shows a characteristic onion-skin periosteal reaction on X-ray.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild, intermittent knee pain for 6 months. X-ray shows an eccentric, lytic lesion in the proximal tibial metaphysis without periosteal reaction. Biopsy reveals stellate cells in a myxoid background. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chondromyxoid Fibroma

 

Explanation:

A teenager presenting with mild intermittent pain and an Xray showing an eccentric, lytic lesion in the proximal tibial metaphysis without periosteal reaction with a biopsy showing stellate cells in a myxoid background is suggestive of Chondromyxoid Fibroma.

Chondromyxoid Fibroma

The least common, benign cartilaginous bone tumor

Demographics

Sex: Slightly more common in males.

Age: Teenagers and young adults (2nd and 3rd decade of life).

Location

Metaphyses of long bones,

particularly the proximal tibia and pelvis.

Presentation

Slow-growing swelling with pain

Radiology

X-ray:

Small, metaphyseal, eccentric lytic lesions, lying parallel to the bone's long axis.

The cortex is expanded, thin, and interrupted. Medullary margins are scalloped and sclerosed.

 

It erupts through the cortex with minimal periosteal or soft tissue reaction.

 

Histology

Stellate cells on a myxoid background. Mitotic figures are rare, though cellular atypia may occur.

Treatment

Small tumors: Local excision and bone grafting

large tumors: Wide en bloc excision

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A) typically presents with aggressive features, such as a sunburst periosteal reaction and pain worsening at night.

 

Osteoid Osteoma (Option C) usually causes severe, night-time pain, is relieved by NSAIDs, and has a small central nidus on imaging.

 

Giant Cell Tumor (Option D) is more common in the epiphysis, often with expansile and lytic lesions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with localized pain and joint stiffness around the knee. Radiographic examination reveals a well-defined lytic lesion in the epiphysis of a long bone. Histological analysis shows a "wet-sawdust" appearance and "chicken-wire" calcification. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

choices.text: It is most commonly diagnosed in patients over 35 years of age.
They are confined within the epiphyses of long bones.
Recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases after treatment.
It is more prevalent in females compared to males.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases after treatment.

 

Explanation:

This case points towards a diagnosis of Chondroblastoma. Recurrence of chondroblastoma is observed in about 10% of cases, indicating the need for careful monitoring.

Chondroblastoma

 

  • Type: Benign but potentially aggressive bone tumor
  • Commonly Affected Age Group: Primarily affects children and adolescents (Option A ruled out)

Epidemiology

Aspect

Details

Prevalence

< 1% of all bone neoplasms

Age Distribution

Peak incidence at 10-20 years; rare <10 or >35 years

Gender

More prevalent in males than females (Option D ruled out)

Clinical Presentation

  • Main Symptom: Localized pain
  • Additional Symptoms: Joint effusion and stiffness, especially near joints

Location

  • Typical Sites:
    • Epiphyses of long bones (especially around the knee)
    • Potential extension across the physis (growth plate) (Option B ruled out)

Radiographic Features

Feature

Description

Appearance

Well-defined, round or oval lytic lesions

Size

Typically 1 to 7 cm

Cortical Expansion

May show expansion without breach

MRI Characteristics

Homogeneous high-signal lesions

 

Histological Features

  • Microscopic Appearance: Characteristic "wet-sawdust" appearance
  • Key Components:
    • Chondroid matrix
    • Calcification
    • Hemorrhage
  • Pathognomonic Features:
    • "Chicken-wire" calcification

    • ABC-like areas in ~35% of cases

Treatment Options

Treatment

Description

Curettage

Tumor scraping with/without bone grafting

Radiofrequency Ablation

Minimally invasive heat treatment

En-bloc Resection

Aggressive removal with healthy margin for recurrence

Joint Preservation

Focus on maintaining adjacent joint integrity

Recurrence

  • Approximately 10% chance of recurrence (Option C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a well-defined, radiolucent lesion in the distal phalanx of the hand. Radiographic findings reveal rounded, lobulated edges with characteristic "popcorn-like" opacities. The lesion measures 4 cm in diameter and is asymptomatic. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serial X-rays for monitoring

 

Explanation:

Serial X-rays for monitoring are appropriate for asymptomatic chondromas, as they typically stop growing after skeletal maturity.

Chondroma: Summary of X-ray Findings and Treatment

X-ray Findings

  • Chondromas present as:
    • Well-defined, radiolucent lesions
    • Surrounded by a thin border of reactive sclerosis
  • Typically located centrally in the bone with:
    • Rounded, lobulated edges
  • Internal characteristics:
    • "Popcorn-like," "glandular," or "ring-like" opacities indicating calcification

  • Rarely exceed 6 cm in diameter

Treatment

  • Asymptomatic Chondromas: No treatment required : (Option D ruled out)
  • Symptomatic Chondromas: Treatment options include:
    • Curettage: (Option A ruled out)
      • Scraping out tumor tissue from the bone
      • Recommended for symptomatic lesions in the hand or in cases of pathological fractures
    • Serial X-rays: (Option B- more appropriate)
      • Monitor size changes post-skeletal maturity
      • Growth after maturity may indicate malignant transformation, necessitating further evaluation and treatment

Immediate surgical excision (Option C): Not necessary since the lesion is asymptomatic and likely benign.

questions.text: An X-ray image shows multiple large chondromas in the hands and feet of a 28-year-old female patient. Based on this radiological finding, which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: The presence of large chondromas may indicate a higher risk of malignant transformation.
These chondromas can lead to bone expansion and thinning of the cortex.
Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.
Patients with multiple chondromas have an increased risk of extra-skeletal malignancies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.

 

Explanation:

It is a case of Multiple Enchondromatosis associated with Maffucci syndrome.

Surgical excision may be indicated for symptomatic chondromas or those showing signs of malignant transformation, it is not necessary to excise all chondromas as a preventive measure.

 

Multiple Enchondromatosis

  • Definition: Condition characterized by numerous benign cartilaginous tumors (chondromas).
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Ollier's disease- only enchondromas
    • Maffucci syndrome- enchondromas + hemangiomas

Ollier's Disease

Feature

Details

Clinical Presentation

Usually diagnosed in childhood

Most chondromas found in phalangeal bones

Common findings:

Asymmetric limb shortening

Swelling of fingers/toes

Impaired movement of interphalangeal joints

Distribution

Can be unilateral or bilateral

Progression

New chondromas typically stop after puberty

Tumor growth in adulthood may indicate malignancy

Risk of pathological fractures

Malignant Transformation

20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma

Transformation usually occurs in the 30s or 40s

Warning signs:

Increase in size of existing chondroma

New symptoms

Maffucci Syndrome

General Features of Multiple Chondromas

Feature

Details
   

Clinical Presentation

Multiple chondromas with hemangiomas



 

Symptoms can appear at birth or later

Radiographic Features

X-rays show large chondromas


 

Possible bone expansion and cortex thinning (Option B ruled out)

Malignant Transformation

Risk of secondary chondrosarcoma > 50% (Option A ruled out)

Similar timing for malignant transformation as Ollier's disease

Increased risk for carcinomas (breast, liver, ovary) (Option D ruled out)

 

Radiographic Appearance

Large chondromas visible on X-rays

Histological Features

Higher cellularity and proliferative potential compared to solitary chondromas


 

Feature

Details

Malignant Transformation

Concern for secondary sarcoma in both conditions

Signs:

Increase in lesion size

New symptoms (e.g., pain)

MRI evidence of new soft-tissue mass

Histological permeative growth pattern

Extra-skeletal Malignancies

Higher risk for tumors in breast, liver, ovaries, CNS
  • Etiology: No definitive cause identified; emphasis on clinical and radiographic findings and risk of malignancy.

Reference:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with a chondroma following imaging and histological examination. Which of the following statements regarding chondromas is false?

choices.text: Chondromas are generally slow-growing, ceasing post-skeletal maturity.
Most chondromas are symptomatic and present with pain or fractures.
Chondromas commonly occur in the tubular bones of the hand.
Serial X-rays can help monitor for malignant transformation in chondromas.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Most chondromas are symptomatic and present with pain or fractures.

 

Explanation:

Most chondromas are asymptomatic and are often discovered incidentally rather than presenting with pain or fractures.

Chondroma: Etiology and Clinical Features

Etiology

  • Incidence:
    • Unknown due to the asymptomatic nature of most chondromas, which are often found incidentally.

Clinical Features

Aspect

Details

Location

Predominantly found in tubular bones of the hand. (Option C ruled out)

Other common sites include the femur and humerus.

Symptoms

Mostly asymptomatic; often discovered via radiography.

May cause pain or pathological fractures in some cases.

Growth

Generally slow-growing, ceasing post-skeletal maturity. (Option A ruled out)

Malignant Transformation

Typically benign, but differentiation from low-grade chondrosarcoma (grade 1) is challenging.

Indicators of chondrosarcoma include:

Increased cellularity

Enlarged nuclei

Presence of multiple double-nucleated cells

Infiltration into marrow spaces and haversian system

Serial X-rays are useful for monitoring potential malignancy; growth post-skeletal maturity may signal transformation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a bony swelling near his knee. He denies pain or any recent trauma. X-ray shows a pedunculated bony outgrowth growing away from the joint, with a thin outer cortex and cancellous structure. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Observation and follow-up

 

Explanation:

Asymptomatic osteochondromas typically do not require treatment unless there are signs of complications such as pain, nerve compression, or concern for malignancy.

Osteochondroma: X-ray, Treatment, and Complications

X-ray Appearance

  • Bony protuberance with distinct edges.
  • Widened host bone cortex extending into the osteochondroma.
  • Features may include:
    • Thin outer cortex, cancellous structure.
    • Pedunculated (cauliflower-like) or sessile base.
    • Pedunculated types grow away from joints, toward the diaphysis.

MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness (Option C ruled out)

  • Reserved for cases where malignant transformation is suspected.

Biopsy to rule out malignancy (Option D ruled out)

  • Indicated without symptoms such as pain or rapid growth.

Treatment

  • Asymptomatic osteochondromas: No treatment required. (Option B)
  • Excision indicated for: (Option A ruled out)
    • Large lesions causing pressure.
    • Concern for malignant transformation in adults.

Complications

Complication

Description

Painful bursa formation

Due to friction over the osteochondroma.

Activity-related discomfort

General discomfort with movement.

Nerve compression

Rare, may cause neuropathic symptoms.

Fracture

Uncommon, results in sudden pain.

Malignant transformation

Rare progression to chondrosarcoma, more likely with a cartilage cap >1.5 cm.
  • Malignant transformation risk factors:
    • Large cartilage cap (>1.5 cm on MRI).
    • Osteochondroma location: More common in the trunk, rare in extremities.
    • Risk Factors: Increased size or new pain after skeletal maturity, especially in Multiple Osteochondromas.

Reference:

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with a painless, hard mass near his proximal humerus. Imaging reveals a bony protuberance with a well-defined cortex that flares into the lesion. Which of the following radiographic features is most indicative of osteochondroma?

choices.text: Joint erosion adjacent to the lesion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cortical flaring into the lesion

 

Explanation:

The characteristic radiographic feature of osteochondroma is the flaring of the host bone's cortex into the osteochondroma, indicating a benign growth.

Osteochondroma:

  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • Growth via enchondral ossification, similar to normal bone development.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, especially the femur and humerus.

Clinical Presentation

  • Usually presents as a painless mass.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Formation of a bursa due to friction.
    • Activity-related discomfort.
  • Rare symptoms:
    • Neuropathic pain from nerve compression.
    • Sudden pain due to fracture.

Types of Osteochondromas and Malignant Transformation

Type

Characteristics

Risk of Malignant Transformation

Solitary Osteochondroma

Low risk (~1%). Difficult to determine exact incidence.

~1%

Multiple Osteochondromas (MO)

Higher risk (~4%). Autosomal dominant disorder with EXT1 or EXT2 gene mutations in 90% of cases.

~4%
  • Factors affecting malignant transformation:
    • Larger lesions with thicker cartilage caps (especially >1.5 cm).
    • More common in trunk lesions, and rare in extremities.
    • Suspicious changes in size or pain after skeletal maturity in MO patients.

Radiographic Appearance

  • Bony protuberance with well-defined borders.
  • Key radiographic features:
    • Cortex flaring into the osteochondroma. (Option B)
    • Thin outer cortex with inner cancellous structure.
    • Pedunculated (cauliflower-like summit) or broad sessile base.
    • Pedunculated lesions point away from the joint toward the diaphysis.



  • MRI findings:
    • Cartilaginous cap thickness, generally thicker in children and thins with age.

Note: Tumor appears small in radiograph and large when palpated because of the cartilage cap.

Sclerotic margins with central lucency (Option A): This is more suggestive of a bone cyst or other lesions, not osteochondroma.

Irregular spiculated margins (Option C): These are typically seen in malignant bone tumors, such as osteosarcoma.

Joint erosion adjacent to the lesion (Option D): Osteochondromas usually do not cause joint erosion, as they grow away from the joint.
